I should add that this plugin worked with build 200406170800, and since there 
shouldn't have been any breaking changes introduced since then, I'm assuming 
that Eclipse is at fault rather than the plugin.
Strange, I don't see any changes in the code between I200406170800 and
I200406172123 that could account for this.

Which VM are you using?  Does the problem occur if you disable the JIT by
running with:
eclipse -vmargs -Djava.compiler=none

Are you the developer of the Spring IDE?
Would you be willing to help track this down further (narrowing which build it
started appearing in really helps, thanks).
Does the problem occur in build 200406172123 when following the -exact- same
steps as in build I200406170800, or could there be some other difference?

Would you be able to run the same scenario under the debugger?  I can provide
instructions if needed.  Alternatively, you could provide me with instructions
on setting up the scenario.

I'm using the Sun VM - build 1.4.2_04-b05. I'll try to dl some additional 
builds Eclipse builds to try and narrow things down.

I'm not the developer of the Spring IDE, btw.
Thanks for helping.

Does it always fail in I200406172123 and later?
That is:
- open Properties view
- open the Spring view
- select something in it
- no properties shown

Or is it intermittent?

In the stack above, it looks like you were switching between parts in the same
folder.  Is this necessary to reproduce the problem?

I was almost 100% sure that this was the build that was working with the 
Spring IDE, but now I don't know what to think - not sure if the exception 
above is somehow due to the small differences in setup. I'm now downloading 
build 200406160800 to see if maybe this was the working one. Will also try 
with the JIT disabled and report. 
Here at home, with build 200406170800, a single click on a tree item (a bean) 
in the beans view, results in the stack trace above. I start eclipse with an 
empty log and the beans view visible docked below the package explorer view 
and the properties view visible as the top of stacked views below source 
editor view. No exceptions logged until I expand a config set in the beans 
vies, expand an application context to show the bean elements and click on one 
of the beans. This should result in the details for that bean being shown in 
the properties view. The way these details are displayed, btw, is in a 
multiply nested tree view.
Turned the JIT off in build 200406170800 but still got the exception reported 
for that build. Tried 200406160800 and got the same exception. I don't know 
that I can do much more here at home to try to identify a working build as I'm 
very sure that it _was_ working with build 200406170800 (small chance that it 
was 200406160800) at work. This will have to wait until Monday when I can 
maybe try a few combinations there.
Looks like the problem existed even in the older builds. I have several Spring 
projects with several bean context definition files in my workspace and only 
in one of them I get this exception when clicking on a bean in the beans view. 
I'll assume that it's a plugin problem for now. You can close this for now and 
I'll re-open it if the plugin's developer indicates that I should do so.
I think the bug in comment #6 is different than the one originally reported.

The one in comment #6 is almost certainly a problem with the plugin.  It's
failing due to a null element field, but ResourcePropertySource does not modify
this field after construction.

Is the bean in question special in some way from the others?  Does it have an
underlying resource or is it somehow virtual?

I could still use your help trying to track down the original problem.
I've filed bug 68024 to add asserts to the constructor of ResourcePropertySource
and FilePropertySource.
It seems that the first exception is generated if, after the first exception is 
thrown, I click on additional beans. These subsequent clicks generate the first 
reported exception. Oddly, can't really see a pattern, I managed to have the 
properties view update to show the details on one bean, clicked on another bean 
which generated the refreshChildEntries NPE, clicked again on the bean that did 
display but this time it also generated an exception. 
> the first exception is generated if, after the first exception is thrown

Sorry, which one occurs first?  I assume you mean the one in comment #6 occurs
first.  This would explain the subsequent failure in comment #0.

The original NPE happens on line 436 of PropertySheetEntry, which is:
  entryCache.put(childEntries[i].getDescriptor().getId(), childEntries[i]);

So either entryCache, childEntries[i], or childEntries[i].getDescriptor() is
null.  entryCache is initialized 2 lines above, so it's not null.


In both PropertySheetEntry.createChildEntries and
PropertySheetEntry.refreshChildEntries(), it assigns childEntries before filling
it in, so it could have null entries if an exception occurs while filling it in.
Although this isn't directly shown in either of the stacks above, it could
happen if the property source is failing, as it is in the stack in comment #6.
Were there any earlier stack traces in the log?

The Properties view should be more resilient to a failure in the property source.

Yes, they happen in the order you assumed and no, there were no prior stack 
traces in the log.
Did a bit of software archeology.  This problem was first seen in bug 6331, but
the code was not properly bullet-proofed to handle failure of the property source.
Created an attachment (id=12609)
Patch to org.eclipse.ui.ide to add an assert to ResourcePropertySource's
constructor
Created an attachment (id=12610)
Patch to org.eclipse.ui.views to make PropertySheetEntry and friends more
resilient to failure of the source

In your message you asked to see if the situation improved with the patch 
applied. In what way should it have improved?
The property sheet view should now no longer fail at a later time if there was a
failure during PropertySheetEntry.createChildEntries() or
PropertySheetEntry.refreshChildEntries().  That is, even if you hit the latest
error above, you should be able to change the selection to some other object and
have the property sheet update properly (unless the new selection also has a
problem).

The stack is comment #18 is really a failure of the spring framework.  It should
not be trying to construct a ResourcePropertySource on a null resource.
Can you report this against the spring framework?
Marking this PR for consideration for 3.0.1.
Not critical for 3.0.1.
Well, we never found the original problem, but I've applied the patches here to
make the property viewer updates more atomic.  If the problem reoccurs, it
should be easier to debug.  Please open a separate bug report if you see this again.
I guess it should be 3.1 M6 instead of 3.0 M6 ;)
Yes, thanks.
Verified that the patches are in I20050331-0800.
